title: RL31919
content: According to the Federal Trade Commission, identity theft is the most common complaint from consumers in all 50 states, accounting for over 35% of the total number of complaints received for calendar years 2004-2006. In 2006, out of 674,354 complaints, 36% were related to identity theft. Victim information was misused for various types of fraud, including credit card fraud (25%), phone/utilities fraud (16%), bank fraud (16%), employment-related fraud (14%), government documents/benefits fraud (5%), loan fraud (5%), and other types of fraud (24%). Identity theft can lead to damaged credit records and unauthorized charges. Identity theft complaints include employment-related fraud (14%), government documents or benefits fraud (5%), and loan fraud (5%). Victims may experience damaged credit records, unauthorized credit card charges, and bank withdrawals. Changing phone numbers, social security numbers, and addresses may be necessary. Concerns about identity theft are increasing due to data security breaches. Federal laws can help victims remove inaccurate credit information and unauthorized charges. The report provides an overview of federal laws that assist victims of identity theft in removing inaccurate credit information and unauthorized charges. The Identity Theft Assumption Deterrence Act prohibits fraud with identification documents, including cases of consumer identity theft. Impostors could face criminal prosecution under this statute. The Identity Theft Assumption Deterrence Act prohibits fraud related to identification documents, including consumer identity theft. Impostors could be prosecuted for producing or possessing stolen identification documents. Transferring or using another person's identification without lawful authority is also a federal crime. The Identity Theft Assumption Deterrence Act prohibits fraud related to identification documents, including consumer identity theft. It is a federal crime to knowingly transfer or use another person's identification without lawful authority. Punishments for offenses involving fraud with identification documents vary depending on the specific offense and type of document. For example, fines or imprisonment up to 15 years may be imposed for using another person's identification with the intent to commit unlawful activity. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act, signed on July 15, 2004, establishes penalties for aggravated identity theft and amends Title 18 of the United States Code. Offenses involving identity theft can result in fines or imprisonment of up to 15 years, with harsher penalties for crimes related to drug trafficking, violence, or international terrorism. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act, signed on July 15, 2004, defines penalties for aggravated identity theft under Title 18 of the United States Code. Aggravated identity theft occurs when a person unlawfully uses another person's identification during certain felonies, resulting in a two-year imprisonment in addition to the original felony punishment. Offenses related to terrorism can lead to an additional five-year imprisonment. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act of 2004 increases penalties for aggravated identity theft, with a two-year imprisonment for the offense in addition to the punishment for the original felony. Offenses related to terrorism can result in an additional five-year imprisonment. The act also allocates funds to the Justice Department for investigating and prosecuting identity theft and related fraud cases. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act of 2004 increased penalties for identity theft and allocated funds to the Justice Department for investigating and prosecuting related fraud cases. The Fair Credit Reporting Act offers victims assistance in removing negative information from their credit files. The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) ensures consumer reporting agencies maintain accurate and fair procedures for consumer credit information. It outlines consumer rights, permissible credit report uses, and disclosure requirements. The FCRA mandates accuracy in reported information and allows consumers to sue for violations, such as inaccurate credit reporting or identity theft. The FCRA mandates accuracy in reported information and allows consumers to sue for violations, such as inaccurate credit reporting or identity theft. Consumers can file suit within two years of discovering a violation or within five years of the violation occurring. The FACT Act, signed in 2003, includes amendments to the FCRA. The FACT Act, signed in 2003, amended the Fair Credit Reporting Act to address identity theft and fraud concerns. Credit card issuers must follow specific procedures under the FCRA when receiving requests for additional or replacement cards after a change of address notification. The FACT Act, signed in 2003, amended the Fair Credit Reporting Act to address identity theft and fraud concerns. Credit card issuers are now required to follow certain procedures when receiving requests for additional or replacement cards after a change of address notification. Additionally, new provisions aim to prevent identity theft by truncating credit card account numbers on receipts and social security numbers on credit reports. Consumers can now request fraud alerts to be placed in their files, with one agency notifying others of the alert. Consumers can request fraud alerts to be placed in their credit files, which are then shared with other consumer reporting agencies. These alerts can be maintained for 90 days or extended up to seven years. Victims of identity theft can also block information resulting from the crime on their credit reports. Victims of identity theft can request a fraud alert to be placed on their credit file, which must be included in any credit score generated using their information. They can also block information related to the crime from their credit reports after providing proof of identity theft. This blocked information must be shared with other consumer reporting agencies. The Fair Credit Billing Act (FCBA) does not specifically address identity theft but allows consumers to request information about alleged fraudulent transactions. Consumer reporting agencies must block and notify furnishers of potentially fraudulent information, and victims can request transaction records with proof of identity theft. The Fair Credit Billing Act (FCBA) allows consumers to request information about alleged fraudulent transactions, including unauthorized charges and charges for goods or services not accepted or delivered. It aims to protect consumers against inaccurate credit billing practices. The Fair Credit Billing Act (FCBA) establishes procedures for resolving billing errors in consumer credit transactions, including unauthorized charges and charges for goods or services not received. Consumers can file claims with creditors to have errors resolved, and they are not required to pay disputed amounts until the issue is resolved. The act also outlines dispute resolution procedures and requires investigations into consumer claims. If a billing error is confirmed, the creditor must correct it and credit the consumer's account. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) provides a framework for resolving unauthorized transactions in electronic fund transfers. It allows consumers to challenge errors and have their accounts recredited. The EFTA limits consumer liability for unauthorized electronic fund transfers. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) allows consumers to challenge unauthorized transactions and limits their liability for such transfers. It establishes rights, liabilities, and responsibilities for participants in electronic fund transfer systems. If a consumer reports a lost or stolen card within two business days, their liability is limited to $50 or the amount of unauthorized transfers before notification. Financial institutions must provide documentation of all electronic transfers initiated by the consumer. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) limits consumer liability for unauthorized transfers to $50 or the amount of the unauthorized transfers before notice. Financial institutions must provide documentation of all electronic fund transfers initiated by the consumer. If a consumer believes there is an error in the documentation, they must notify the financial institution within 60 days, and the institution must investigate and report the results within 10 business days. The consumer must notify the financial institution of any error in electronic fund transfer documentation within 60 days. The institution must investigate and report the results within 10 business days. If an error is confirmed, it must be corrected within one day, and the consumer's account may be provisionally recredited. The financial institution can provisionally recredit the consumer's account for alleged errors pending investigation. The President's Identity Theft Task Force recommended a plan to combat identity theft by utilizing government resources, strengthening protection of personal information, educating consumers and businesses, and enhancing safeguards on personal data. The President's Identity Theft Task Force recommended a plan to combat identity theft by strengthening protection of personal information, educating consumers and businesses, and enhancing safeguards on personal data. The Plan focuses on improvements in four key areas: data security, making it difficult for identity thieves, assisting victims in recovery, and deterring theft through aggressive prosecution. Recommendations include amending statutes for increased federal prosecution of identity theft-related offenses. The President's Identity Theft Task Force recommended amendments to federal criminal statutes to prosecute identity theft-related offenses more effectively. Recommendations include adding new crimes to the list of predicate offenses for aggravated identity theft, penalizing creators of malicious spyware, and enhancing sentences for identity thieves. Amend statutes to criminalize theft of electronic data, penalize creators of malicious spyware, and enhance sentences for identity thieves. Implement Real ID Act standards for state-issued driver's licenses and identification cards. The Real ID Rule establishes standards for state-issued driver's licenses and identification cards to meet the requirements of the REAL ID Act of 2005. States can receive extensions until December 31, 2009, and those meeting security benchmarks can get a second extension until May 10, 2011. The Rule also extends the enrollment period for states. The Real ID Rule extends deadlines for states to comply with security benchmarks for licenses and identification cards. States can receive extensions until December 31, 2009, and those meeting certain criteria can get a second extension until May 10, 2011. The rule requires states to replace all licenses with REAL ID-compliant cards by specific dates based on birth year.
